s.text: This spot doesn't overtly link Rodriguez with the man whose mantle he is trying to win.

Rodriguez (like Solis and Tejeda before him) is considered a Mexican-American success story, a local who overcame cultural, class, and linguistic barriers to rise to positions of leadership in the area.

Rodriguez (like Solis and Tejeda before him) is considered a Mexican-American success story, a local who overcame cultural, class, and linguistic barriers to rise to positions of leadership in the area.

Rodriguez (like Solis and Tejeda before him) is considered a Mexican-American success story, a local who overcame cultural, class, and linguistic barriers to rise to positions of leadership in the area.

The 10-year Texas House veteran has a strong track record on the issue: Not only did he make it his priority during his tenure in the Legislature and through 12 years as a school-board member before that, but he has also identified it as a key issue in the second round of campaigning ahead of the runoff.
His appeal aims to strike the balance of people politics, community, and patriotism that was Tejeda's hallmark through his years in office.
What could seem at first glance self-important strikes a chord nonetheless--and in this Hispanic district, this kind of visual cue can't hurt.
The call for solidarity reaches beyond the issue at hand to tap a deeper sense of ethnic and cultural identification.

Ciro Rodriguez for Congress , which ran during the special election, responds to Solis' challenge, to his niche appeal in a district that is also home to two Air Force bases (with presumably more conservative and fewer Hispanic voters), by playing to Rodriguez's strength--education.

Ciro Rodriguez for Congress , which ran during the special election, responds to Solis' challenge, to his niche appeal in a district that is also home to two Air Force bases (with presumably more conservative and fewer Hispanic voters), by playing to Rodriguez's strength--education.

Tejeda's district is only 9 percent African-American, but the spot makes this politically correct nod to diversity and to the blacks enlisted at the Air Force bases that are the lifeblood of the area.
Repeating visuals flow fast and furious--a shot of an empty classroom; of someone donning graduation robes; of the empty classroom; of the faces in the library; of the robes.
The spot's directness thus far papers over the tired language--and the camera moves swiftly to Rodriguez facing his student audience again, asking once more: "Are you with me?"
